questions.text: A child was encouraged by his parents to follow a healthy lifestyle to prevent obesity. What level of prevention is adopted in this scenario?
questions.solution:
Primordial prevention is adopted in this scenario.

The emergence of risk factors for obesity is prevented by encouraging the child to follow a healthy lifestyle from an early age. This reduces the probability of developing obesity in the future.

Primordial prevention is the prevention of the emergence of risk factors in populations in which they have not yet appeared. Most adult health problems have their origins in childhood. Efforts are directed toward discouraging children from adopting harmful lifestyles. The main intervention in primordial prevention is by individual and mass education.

Other options:

Option A: Primary prevention is the action taken before the onset of the disease. This removes the possibility of the occurrence of a disease. Here, intervention is initiated in the pre-pathogenesis phase of a disease. It is accomplished by population strategy and high-risk strategy. Examples of primary prevention are immunization and sanitizing hands.

Option C: Secondary prevention is halting the progress of a disease at its incipient stage and preventing complications. Intervention is initiated in the early pathogenesis phase. Measures like early diagnosis and treatment are used to arrest the disease progression. Examples of secondary prevention are pap smear for early detection of cervical cancer and mammography to pick up breast cancer.

Option D: Tertiary prevention is the action taken to limit impairment and promote rehabilitation of patients in case of irreversible damage. Intervention is done in the late pathogenesis phase. An example is rehabilitation is providing walking aid for the crippled.

questions.text:
A child was brought to the primary health center for vaccination. The parents informed the medical officer that the child had a history of egg allergy. Which of the following vaccines can not be given to the child?
  1. Yellow fever
  2. Japanese encephalitis
  3. Bacille Calmette-Guerin (BCG)
  4. Influenza
  5. Measles, Mumps, and Rubella (MMR)
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, yellow fever and influenza vaccines cannot be given to a child who has an egg allergy.

Yellow fever and influenza vaccines are prepared in hen's egg tissues. Hence, they cannot be given to a patient with a history of anaphylactic reactions following egg ingestion. However, vaccine viruses propagated in chicken fibroblast cells like measles or MMR vaccines can be given.

questions.text: A Ph.D scholar wants to study the etiological factors leading to the development of Moebius syndrome. Which study design should she use?
questions.solution:
Moebius syndrome is a rare disease, so a case-control study should be used by the researcher to study the etiology of this disease.

The case-control study is a comparison or cross-reference study with individuals as the unit of study. It is also called a retrospective study and is a good analytical design to study rare diseases. This study is the first approach to test causal hypotheses.

The case-control method has three distinct features:

  1. Both exposure and outcome (disease) have occurred before the start of the study
  2. The study proceeds backward from effect to cause
  3. It uses a control/comparison group to support/reject an inference 

Other options:

Option A - Cohort study is a follow-up study with individuals as the unit of study. It is used for the study of multiple outcomes related to exposure of study. It can not be used when the exposure under investigation is rare.

Option B - Cross-sectional study is a prevalence study with individuals as the unit of study. It is also known as a prevalence study and is more useful for the study of chronic diseases. It is more appropriate for the study of the distribution of a disease in a population than studying its etiology.

Option D - Ecological study is a correlational study with the population as the unit of study.

Related Pearl: Case Control Study

In a case-control study, progression is from effect (disease) to cause (exposure) as the outcome or disease has already occurred. It is also called a retrospective study.

Design of case-control study:

 

  • Steps of case control study:
    • Selection of cases and controls
    • Matching
    • Measurement of exposure
    • Analysis in the form of exposure rates, risk ratio, and odds ratio
  • Advantages of case control study:
    • Easy to carry out, rapid and inexpensive
    • Requires few subjects, no risk to subjects
    • Used to investigate rare diseases
    • Different etiological factors can be studied and risk factors can be identified
    • No attrition problems, minimal ethical problems
  • Disadvantages of case control study:
    • Relies on memory or past records giving rise to bias
    • Selection of appropriate control groups is difficult
    • Incidence cannot be measured
    • Does not distinguish between causes and associated factors
    • Not suited for evaluation of therapy or prophylaxis
    • Representativeness of the cases and controls is often inadequate

Related Pearl: Cohort Study

  • A cohort study progresses from cause (exposure) to effect (disease).
  • It is also known as forward-looking study, incidence study, prospective study, and longitudinal study.
  • Design of a cohort study:
    • Types of cohort study:
      • Prospective (concurrent) cohort studies
      • Retrospective (historical) cohort studies
      • Combination cohort studies
    • Steps of cohort study:
      • Selection of study subjects
      • Obtaining data on exposure
      • Selection of comparison groups
      • Follow-up
      • Analysis in terms of incidence rates and estimation of risk
    • Advantages of cohort study:
      • Incidence can be calculated
      • Several possible outcomes related to exposure can be studied at the same time
      • Provides direct estimate of relative risk
      • Calculation of dose-response ratio
      • Minimization of certain biases
    • Disadvantages of cohort study:
      • Cannot use for uncommon diseases
      • Expensive, requires a large population and longer time
      • Many common administrative and ethical problems
      • High attrition and selection of subjects is difficult
      • Dynamism of diagnostics is difficult to incorporate
      • Tends to alter the behaviour of subjects known as Hawthorne effect.

questions.text:
A child who was bitten by a stray dog was immediately brought to the primary health center. He had an abrasion on his left leg with minor bleeding. Which of the following measures should be taken immediately in this case to stop the contraction of rabies?
  1. Wash the wound with soap and water for 15 minutes
  2. Irrigate the wound with cetrimide and chlorhexidine.
  3. Infiltrate the wound with rabies immunoglobulin
  4. Administer the cell culture-derived rabies vaccine
  5. Suture the wound immediately
questions.solution:
The wound of the child bitten by a stray dog should be washed with soap and water for 15 minutes. This is followed by irrigation of the wound with cetrimide and chlorhexidine. Since there is bleeding from the wound it belongs to Category III. Rabies vaccine and immunoglobulin should be administered.

The following measures should be taken immediately to stop the contraction of rabies:

  • Cleansing - The most important step in the prevention of rabies is washing the affected area with plenty of soap and water under a running tap for 15 minutes. This is a standard procedure that minimizes the contraction of rabies.
  • Chemical treatment - Irrigation of the wound should then be done with virucidal agents like alcohol, tincture, 0.01% solution of aqueous iodine, or povidone-iodine. Even irrigating the wound with cetrimide + chlorhexidine solution can be done. This process eliminates the residual virus in the wound.
  • Suturing - Bite wounds are not sutured generally. If suturing is necessary, it is done after 24-48 hours under the cover of local infiltration of the rabies immunoglobulin which is generally done in category III wounds.
  • Other measures - Local antibiotics and tetanus toxoid should be given.

Different wound categories for post-exposure prophylaxis:

Categories of wound Post-exposure prophylaxis
Category I - touching or feeding animals, licks on intact skin None
Category II - nibbling of uncovered skin, minor scratches, or abrasions
without bleeding		 Immediate vaccination and
local treatment of the wound
Category III- single or multiple transdermal bites or scratches, licks on broken skin contacts with bats Immediate vaccination and
administration of rabies
immunoglobulin; local
treatment of the wound

 

Related Pearl: Rabies vaccines and immunoglobulins schedules

According to the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare, Government of India:

WHO category II or III exposures should receive post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP) immediately.

One intradermal (ID) dose is 0.1 mL of vaccine and one intramuscular (IM) dose is an entire vial of vaccine, irrespective of the vial size.

Should a vaccine dose be delayed for any reason, the PEP schedule should be resumed (not restarted).

Rabies Immunoglobulin(RIG): 

  • Passive immunization
  • Single-dose; after initiation of PEP and not beyond 7 days after the first dose of vaccine
  • Max dose: hRIG - 20IU/kg , eRIG - 40IU/kg body weight
  • Vaccines should never be withheld regardless of the availability of RIG.
  • Alternatives for RIG- WHO recommends monoclonal antibodies (mAb) as a 'cocktail' containing at least two antibodies against the rabies virus.

Administration of RIG:

  • RIG should be administered into or around the wound site or sites.
  • The remaining RIG, if any, should be injected IM at a site distant from the site of vaccine administration.
  • RIG may be diluted to a volume sufficient for all wounds to be effectively and safely infiltrated.

Prioritization of RIG allocation (numbered according to priority order):

  1. Multiple bites
  2. Deep wounds
  3. Bites to head, neck, and hands
  4. Patients with severe immunodeficiency
  5. Confirmed/probable rabies in biting animal
  6. Bites, scratches, and exposure of mucous membranes caused by a bat

Pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP)

PrEP is considered in the following conditions:

  • High-risk groups- laboratory staff, wildlife wardens, veterinarians, animal handlers, and travelers to endemic regions.
  • Remote, rabies-endemic areas where access to PEP is difficult
  • Areas where dog bite incidence is >5% per year
  • Areas where vampire bat rabies is known to be present.

Pre-exposure rabies vaccination consists of 3 intramuscular (IM) or 3 intradermal (ID) doses. These are given on days 0, 7 and 21 or 28.

  • Adults - the vaccine should always be administered in the deltoid area of the arm
  • Young children (under 1 year of age)- Administration into the anterolateral area of the thigh is recommended.
  • Rabies vaccine should never be administered in the gluteal area. Administration in this manner will result in lower neutralizing antibody titers.

For exposed or re-exposed patients who can document previous completion of PEP or PrEP the following guidelines would be applicable:

  • Proper wound management should be done.
  • There is no need for the administration of RIG.
  • One site ID or IM vaccine administration on days 0 and 3.

Only adequate wound washing would be required in case of re-exposure where the animal bite victim has documented proof of complete PEP within the last three months.

The following cases are treated as fresh cases and given full PEP:

  • Those who have previously received full post-exposure treatment with neural tissue vaccines (NTV) or vaccines of unproven potency
  • Those who cannot document complete PEP or PrEP treatment

questions.text: A 25-year-old patient came to the Suraksha clinic with the following presentation in the right inguinal region.  Which of the following kits should be given to treat this patient?
questions.solution:
The black kit should be used for the treatment of this patient. In the image shown above, the groove sign is seen in the inguinal region. It is the characteristic feature of lymphogranuloma venereum caused by Chlamydia trachomatis.

The black kit comprises of tablet azithromycin 1 gm single dose + tablet doxycycline 100 mg twice daily for 21 days.

It is used in the following presentation:

  • Swelling in the inguinal region may be painful
  • The preceding history of genital ulcer or discharge
  • Systemic symptoms like malaise, fever, etc.

All partners in the last 3 weeks should be treated.

Other options:

Option A - The grey kit is used in men for urethral discharge and scrotal swelling. All recent partners should be treated. However, when used for cervical discharge in women, only symptomatic male partners need to be treated.

Option B - The blue kit is used in non-herpetic genital ulcer disease when the patient is allergic to penicillin. All partners in the last 3 months should be treated.

Option C - The red kit is used in herpetic genital ulcer disease, in which the treatment of asymptomatic partners is not required.

Related Pearl: Syndromic Management of Sexually Transmitted Infections

Partner Management when asymptomatic is not required for Gardenella vaginalis, Candida and Herpes infections.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a part of the key intervention of the Tribal Malaria Action Plan (TMAP)?

choices.text: Faith healers may be trained to diagnose and treat malaria cases
Social marketing to increase usage of mosquito repellent ointments
Provision of diagnosis and treatment facilities to labourers

questions.solution:
Social marketing to increase the usage of mosquito repellant ointments is not a part of the key intervention of the Tribal Malaria Action Plan (TMAP). Social marketing is done to increase the usage of bed nets.

The key interventions of the Tribal Malaria Action Plan (TMAP) are:

  • Strengthening surveillance by the introduction of mobile-based surveillance, where routine health facilities are not available.
  • Provision of hamlet-wise ASHAs instead of village-wise. 
  • Wherever engagement of ASHAs is not possible, anganwadi workers, faith healers, local health care providers, village headmen, school teachers, or forest departments may be trained to diagnose and treat malaria cases.
  • In areas with civic disturbance, well-informed and pre-scheduled mobile health services should be provided.
  • Involvement of locally available, credible NGOs.
  • Strengthening of PHCs with quality microscopy facilities.
  • Mandatory provision of diagnosis and treatment facilities by contractors of development projects to the laborers should be made.
  • On the spot, species-specific radical treatment of all positive malaria cases should be done.
  • Identification of serious cases and early referral to specialized health facilities, ensuring free transport services.
  • Follow-up and epidemiological tracking of all positive cases.
  • Mass screening of migrants wherever necessary.
  • Integrated Vector Management (IVM) for appropriate vector control.
  • Social marketing to increase usage of bed nets.
  • Minor environmental engineering like cleaning drainage, filling pits and ditches, solid waste management should be done through Village Health, Sanitation and Nutrition Committee (VHSN&C), and MNREGA.
  • Regular and efficient supply chain management.
  • Intensive training for all cadres of staff, ASHAs/community volunteers.
  • Community mobilization by utilizing traditional IEC/BCC (Information Education Communication/Behaviour Change Communication) tools and practices. 

Related Pearl: Malaria in the National Vector Borne Disease Control Programme (NVBDCP)

National Framework for Malaria Elimination in India (2016-2030)

  • Goals: To eliminate malaria and maintain malaria-free status.
  • Objectives:
    • By 2022, transmission of malaria interrupted and zero indigenous cases.
    • By 2024, incidence of malaria to be reduced to <1 case per 1000 population.
    • By 2030, malaria to be eliminated throughout the country.

Classification of states/UTs according to the Annual Parasite Index (API):

 

Category  Criteria  Major measures:
Category 0  States/UTs with zero indigenous cases  Detect re-introduced cases and notify and maintain malaria-free status. 
Category 1  Elimination phase – States/UTs with API <1 and all their districts reporting API <1  Interruption of local transmission.
Category 2  Pre-elimination phase – States/UTs with API <1 but some districts reporting API ≥1. 

Screening. 

Setting up one-stop mobile centres/clinics. 

 
Category 3  Intensified control phase – States/UTs with API ≥1.   Same as category 2

 

  • The National Strategic Plan (NSP) for Malaria Elimination (2017-22) was launched by the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare under NVBDCP, which is based on the National Framework for Malaria Elimination (2016 – 2030).
  • The NSP focuses mainly on the districts which function as the operational units.

Accordingly, all the districts are classified into the following four categories:

Category of districts Definition
Category 0: Prevention of re-establishment phase  Includes all districts in which no incidence of malaria was reported in the last 3 years.
Category 1: Elimination phase  Districts with API <1 per 1000 population.
Category 2: Pre elimination phase  Districts with API in between 1-2 per 1000 population.
Category 3: Intensified control phase  Districts with API >2 per 1000 population.

The above classification is more operational than the classification mentioned in the NFME which is state focussed.

The goal of NSP strategy is the phased elimination of malaria in India. The National Framework for Malaria Elimination (NFME) in India has set 2030 as the goal for eliminating malaria, and the goals of NSP in consonance with overall goals.

The goals of NSP 2017 – 2022 are:

  • Eliminate malaria in category 1 (API < 1) districts by 2020, and category 2 (API 1-2) districts by 2022.
  • Reduce transmission in category 3 districts to stabilize API at <1 by 2022.

questions.text: A 70-year-old disabled paraplegia patient from rural area with no family was admitted to a tertiary health center for pneumonia. Which of the following is true regarding the benefits this patient would receive under the Ayushman Bharat - National Health Protection Mission?

choices.text: Treatment for pneumonia would be covered, but treatment for paralysis would not be covered under this program.
Being a disabled citizen with no family, he would be automatically included in the scheme.
The maximum age limit to avail the benefits under this programme is 65 years, so he would not receive any benefits.
A registration fees of rupees 2000 is mandatory before enrolling into the program.

questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, the patient is a disabled citizen with no family so would be automatically included in the National Health Protection Mission which is a component of Ayushman Bharat.

  • D4- Disabled member and no able-bodied adult member
  • D5- SC/ST households
  • D7- Landless households deriving a major part of their income from manual casual labour

Automatically included:

  • Households without shelter
  • Destitute/ living on alms
  • Manual scavenger families
  • Primitive tribal groups
  • Legally released bonded labour

 For Urban:

  • Construction worker/ Plumber/ Mason/ Labour/ Painter/ Welder/ Security guard/

Ayushman Bharat-National Health Protection Mission:

Beneficiary Level: 

  • The government provides health insurance cover of up to Rs. 5,00,000 per family per year.
  • More than 10.74 crore poor and vulnerable families (approximately 50 crore beneficiaries) are covered across the country.
  • All families listed in the Socio-economic caste census (SECC) database as per defined criteria will be covered. 
  • It covers up to 3 days of pre-hospitalization and 15 days post-hospitalization expenses such as diagnostics and medicines.
  • There is no restriction on the family size, age or gender.
  • All pre-existing conditions are covered from day one.
  • Benefits of the scheme are portable across the country i.e. a beneficiary can visit any empanelled public or private hospital in India to avail cashless treatment.
  • Services include approximately 1,393 procedures covering all the costs related to treatment, including but not limited to drugs, supplies, diagnostic services, physician's fees, room charges, surgeon charges, OT and ICU charges etc.
  • Public hospitals are reimbursed for the healthcare services at par with the private hospitals.

questions.text: A 23-year-old man came to you for nutritional advice. He is an alcoholic. Which of the following measures would not prevent the development of Wernicke's encephalopathy?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, vitamin C supplementation would not prevent the development of Wernicke's encephalopathy.

In an alcoholic person, thiamine deficiency can cause Wernicke's encephalopathy. Hence, the measures to prevent thiamine deficiency are:

  • Cessation of alcohol (Option A) 
  • Including gingelly seeds (sesame seeds) in the diet because they have the highest content of thiamine. (Option B)
  • Consuming parboiled rice instead of milled or highly polished rice. Thiamine is lost from rice during the process of milling. (Option C)
  • Direct supplementation with thiamine.

The two principal deficiency diseases of thiamine are:

  1. Beriberi may occur in three main forms :
    • The dry form is characterized by nerve involvement (peripheral neuritis)
    • The wet form is characterized by heart involvement (cardiac beriberi)
    • The infantile form is seen in infants between 2 to 4 months of age. The affected baby is usually breast-fed by a thiamine-deficient mother who commonly shows signs of peripheral neuropathy.
  2. Wernicke's encephalopathy is often seen often in alcoholics. It is characterized by ophthalmoplegia, polyneuritis, ataxia and mental deterioration. It occurs occasionally in people who fast.

High-risk groups for thiamine deficiency are:

  • Lactating mothers
  • Patients on regular haemodialysis
  • Persistent vomiting
  • Prolonged gastric aspiration 
  • People who go on long fasts

High-risk groups should be treated with direct supplementation of thiamine.

Note: Vitamin C supplementation in the dose of 500-1000mg can be used for the prevention and treatment of lathyrism.

questions.text: A  couple married for 11 years lives with their 9-year-old son. What type of family is this?
questions.solution:
The type of family described in the given scenario is a nuclear family. 

Types of families:

  • A nuclear family or elementary family consists of only the married couple and their offspring while they are dependants.
  • The term new family is applied when nuclear families are younger than 10 years and consist of parents and children.
  • A joint family or extended family consists of a number of married couples and their children who live together in the same household with usually the men being related by blood. All property in joint families is held in common with the family income going into a common pocket. A senior male member is usually the head of the family who makes decisions.
  • A three-generation family is one where there are representatives from three different generations in one house.
  • A communal family is one in which all the members play a part in its management.

questions.text:
The audiogram of a laborer working at a mining factory shows the following picture. Which of the following is true?

ESI - Employees State Insurance

choices.text: It is a notifiable disease under the ESI Act, 1948
It is a notifiable disease under Coal Mines Labour Welfare Fund Act, 1947
It is a notifiable disease under the Factories Act, 1948
It is a notifiable disease under Maternity Benefit Act, 2017

questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, the audiogram shows a dip at 4000Hz which is characteristic of noise-induced hearing loss. It is a notifiable disease under the Factories Act, 1948.

The Factories Act, 1948 gives a schedule of notifiable diseases. There are 29 diseases notifiable to the government under this act. The 1976 amendment includes Byssinosis, Asbestosis, occupational dermatitis, and noise-induced hearing loss among the list of notifiable diseases.

Related Pearl: Notifiable occupational diseases

 There are 29 diseases notifiable to the government under the Indian Factories Act 1948, some important ones are:

  • Anthracosis
  • Asbestosis
  • Byssinosis
  • Noise induced hearing loss
  • Occupational dermatitis
  • Occupational cancers
  • Silicosis

Related Pearl: The Factories act, 1948 and The Maternity Act, 2017

The Factories act,1948

The act defines a factory as an establishment employing 10 or more workers where power is used, and 20 or more workers where power is not used. 

Provisions in the age of employment are:

  • Children <14 years are prohibited from working.
  • Adolescents between 15-18 years:
    • Can be employed only in certain industries.
    • They can work only between 6 AM – 7 PM.
    • They should not be made to work for more than four and a half hours.
    • They are allowed to take leave once every 15 days and have an accumulated leave of up to 40 days.

For adults, the maximum hours of work for an industrial worker should be not more than 48 hours per week, not exceeding 9 hours a day. If working overtime, then it should be no more than 60 hours per week including overtime.

Per capita space availability: For factories established after 1948 – min 500cuft / person

Safety and welfare measures include the provision of the following:

  • > 1000 Workers – Safety officer
  • > 500 Workers – Welfare officer
  • > 250 Workers – Canteen
  • > 50 employees - Crèche

The Maternity Act, 2017 is a landmark law that has enhanced the duration of paid maternity leave:

  • Working mothers - 12-26 weeks
  • Working mothers, with 2 surviving children - 12 weeks
  • Adopting mother and commissioning mothers- 12 weeks from the date on which the child is being handed over to the mother.

According to Indian Maternity Benefit (Amendment) Act, 2017: Effective as of the 1st of July 2017, mandatory crèche (daycare) facilities for every establishment employing 50 or more employees (inclusive of men and women).

questions.text: A woman delivers a baby through the cesarean section and returns home after 5 days. How many visits should an ASHA worker make post delivery to evaluate the condition of the newborn and the mother?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, an ASHA worker would make 5 visits post-delivery to evaluate the condition of the newborn and the mother.

The woman delivers a baby through the cesarean section and returns home after 5 days. The ASHA worker should ideally make the first visit on day 7 and, thereafter, 4 visits till day 42.

Home visits of ASHA workers post delivery:

  • 7 visits after home delivery on days 1, 3, 7, 14, 21, 28, and 42
  • 6 visits after institutional delivery on days 3, 7, 14, 21, 28, and 42
  • 5 visits after cesarean section delivery, first visit on day 7, and thereafter 4 visits till day 42

Related Pearl: ASHA

ASHA stands for Accredited Social Health Activist.

General norms with respect to ASHA workers:

  • Must be a woman in the age group of 25-45 years - married/divorced/widow
  • Must be a resident of that village
  • Formal education of up to 10th standard 
    • If no candidates are available, the requirement can be relaxed to the 8th standard
  • At least 1 ASHA for a population of 1000 
    • In tribal, hilly, and desert areas, the norm can be relaxed to 1 ASHA per habitation

States can relax the norms on population and educational qualifications on a case-to-case basis, depending on the local conditions. However, these are exceptions and not the general norm.

Responsibilities of ASHA:

    • Health education and awareness
    • Reproductive and child health and family planning
    • Facilitate the access to health services
    • Promotion of sanitation and household toilet construction
    • Provision of primary medical care for minor ailments
    • Provider of DOTS
    • Depot holder of essentials like ORS, iron and folic acid tablets, condoms, disposable delivery kits, etc.
    • Dispersal of health information on her community to higher centres
    • Some responsibilities are integrated with Anganwadi workers and Auxiliary Nurse Midwife

Home visits by ASHA under Home-based Newborn care (HBNC) 

  • 7 visits after home delivery (on days 1, 3, 7, 14, 21, 28 and 42)
  • 6 visits after institutional delivery (on days 3, 7, 14, 21, 28 and 42) in case of a vaginal delivery; and 5 visits in cases of Caesarean section delivery, where the mother returns home after 5-6 days, i.e, on days - 7, 14, 21, 28 and 42.

questions.text: In a given population, the chance of developing a particular cancer was found to be 40%. What is the probability that all 4 randomly selected people from the population would have cancer?
questions.solution:
In this scenario, the probability of all 4 randomly selected people getting cancer would be 0.0256.

The probability of a person developing cancer in the population is given by p (developing cancer) = 40/100 = 0.4

If 4 people are randomly selected in a population, the chance of the first person having cancer is independent of the second/third/fourth also having it and vice-versa. This satisfies the condition for the multiplication rule of probability. It states that the probability of two or more statistically independent events all occurring is equal to the product of their individual probabilities.

Hence in this scenario, the probability that all 4 randomly selected people from the population would have cancer = 0.4 x 0.4 x 0.4 x 0.4 = 0.0256

Note: The (p) of any one of the 4 randomly selected people from the population having cancer = the sum of their individual probabilities = 0.4 + 0.4 + 0.4 + 0.4 = 1.6

questions.solution:
In the given scenario, mean = median = mode.

The mean is the sum of all the elements divided by the number of elements in the distribution. In this scenario, the mean = (90 + 92 + 92 + 92 + 94) / 5 = 460/ 5= 92%

The median divides the frequency distribution in half when all the scores are listed in order. When a distribution has an odd number of elements, the median is the middle value. When the distribution has an even number of elements, the median is the average of the two middle scores. In this scenario, the median = 92% which is the middle value.

The mode is the observed value that occurs with the greatest frequency. In this scenario, the mode = 92%

Hence, the mean = median = mode = 92%

In a unimodal symmetrical distribution like a normal distribution, all the three measures are approximately the same,  mean = median = mode. In a positively skewed distribution in which the long tail is towards the positive direction, the mean will be larger than the median and mode, i.e., mean > median > mode. In a negatively skewed distribution in which the long tail is towards the negative direction, the mean will be smaller than the median, i.e., mean < median < mode.

Other options:

Options B and C: Mean = Mode = Median = 92%. Hence options B and C are incorrect.

Option D: There is only one value that occurs with the greatest frequency. Hence, the frequency distribution is unimodal. If two values occur with the greatest frequency then the frequency distribution is bimodal. If more than two values occur with the greatest frequency then the distribution is multimodal.

questions.text: An 18-year-old unmarried girl comes to you for advice on contraception. Which of the following contraception methods would you suggest to her?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, a condom should be suggested as a method of contraception in an adolescent unmarried girl. 

Condoms prevent unwanted pregnancies and sexually transmitted infections. It is a barrier method of contraception and is preferable in adolescents. Young, unmarried girls are at risk for getting pregnant who then resort to legal or illegal abortions performed under unsatisfactory conditions. This can increase mortality or cause complications like secondary sterility.

Other options:

Options A and C - Diaphragm and cervical cap are not suitable in adolescents because they are complicated to use and young people lack the skills to use them. These contraception methods also require foreseeing of sexual intercourse which is not possible in young adolescents due to their behavior of having occasional sex with different partners.

Option D - Intra-uterine contraceptive device (IUCD) are contraindicated because of the risk of developing pelvic infection and secondary sterility. 

Note: Oral contraceptive pills (OCPs) are preferred for adolescent girls because they generally do not suffer from any cardiovascular diseases. They are also completely reversible and do not modify the future fertility of these girls. However, OCPs do not protect against HIV/AIDs.

questions.text: The concept of barefoot doctors belongs to which system of medicine?
questions.solution:
The concept of barefoot doctors and acupuncture belongs to modern Chinese medicine.

Chinese medicine claims to be the world's first organized body of medical knowledge, as it dates back to 2700 B.C. They are also the pioneers of immunization and practiced variolation to prevent smallpox.

Other options:

Option A - The Indian system of medicine includes the Ayurveda and the Siddha systems. Ayurveda by definition implies the knowledge of life or the knowledge by which life may be prolonged. Its origin is about 5000 B.C old and is based on the tridosha theory of disease. The two prominent names in Ayurveda are Charaka who wrote the Charak Samhita, and Sushruta (the father of Indian surgery) who wrote the Sushruta Samhita.

Option B - The Egyptian system of medicine excelled in public health. They built planned cities, public baths, and underground drains. They had the knowledge of inoculation against smallpox, the value of mosquito nets, and the association of plague with rats. The book, Edwin Smith papyrus accurately describes partial paralysis following cerebral lesions in skull fractures.

Option C - The Mesopotamian system of medicine classified doctors as herb doctors, knife doctors, and spell doctors. Hammurabi, a king of Babylonian, formulated the first codification for medical practice. He created the Babylonian Code of Hammurabi. It had laws governing the conduct of physicians, health practices, costs, and penalties for harmful therapy. It reflected a high degree of social organization but was devoid of any scientific foundation.

questions.text: A married couple has a child with thalassemia major. What preventive method would you use to prevent giving birth to another thalassemia-positive baby in this couple?
questions.solution:
The preventive method to be used to prevent giving birth to another thalassemia-positive baby in this couple is retrospective genetic counselling.

Retrospective genetic counselling is the most common approach of counselling done presently for hereditary disorders that have already occurred within the family. Under this type of counselling, the couples are suggested contraception, termination of pregnancy, or sterilization, depending on individual considerations.

It is recommended by the WHO to establish sufficient genetic counselling centers in places where infectious diseases and nutritional disorders have been brought under good control. These centers should also be set up in areas where genetic diseases like sickle cell anemia and thalassemia are a major public health concern.

Other options:

Option A - Prospective genetic counselling is an approach used where heterozygous individuals for any particular defect are identified by screening procedures prospectively. The risk of giving birth to affected children if they marry another heterozygous individual with the same defect is been explained to them. This approach is used to reduce the number of heterozygous marriages. This method is applied in diseases like sickle cell anemia and thalassemia.

Option C - Positive eugenics aims at improving the genetic constitution of the population by encouraging people who carry desirable genotypes to bear the burden of becoming parents.

Option D - Euthenics is an approach in which people are given access to a suitable environment to improve their genotype. This is a more practical approach to prevent genetic diseases as it involves the mutual interaction of heredity and environmental factors.

questions.solution:
Culture contact is also known as acculturation.

Acculturation is the process by which there is the diffusion of cultures between two culturally different groups of people. This can happen in the following ways:

  • Trade and commerce
  • Industrialization
  • Religious propagation
  • Education
  • Conquest

Acculturation can influence people in both good and bad ways. Widespread use of tobacco is a bad example of acculturation. However, the introduction of scientific medicine is a good example of acculturation.

Other options -

Options A and C - Customs are the traditionally accepted ways of behaving that are specific to a society. They can be folkways, which are referred to as the right ways of doing things in less vital areas of human conduct. Mores are stringent customs followed by society.

Option D - Role is the function or duties assumed by a person of a particular society.

A globe thermometer can be used for the direct measurement of the mean radiant temperature of the surroundings. It is affected by both the air temperature and radiant heat.

A kata thermometer was originally used to measure the cooling power of the air. It was used to assess the indices of thermal comfort. Currently, it is used only as an anemometer to measure low air velocities.

questions.text: An 8-year-old boy is brought to the clinic by his parents with complaints of fever and rash. The fever developed 5 days back and the rash was first noticed 2 days back on the face, which then progressed to his trunk. He is diagnosed with measles. What is the recommended period of isolation for measles?

choices.text: From onset of rash to 3 days after rash onset
2 weeks before rash to 1 week after rash onset
During full course of the disease
From catarrhal stage to 7 days after rash onset

questions.solution:
The isolation period for measles is from the catarrhal stage to 7 days after the onset of the rash.

The incubation period is commonly 10 days from exposure to onset of fever, and 14 days from appearance of the rash. 

Measles can be divided into 3 phases:

1) The prodromal (catarrhal) stage

The prodromal phase begins at the onset of the first symptoms, which begin gradually and include a fever, a cough, a runny nose, and red eyes. Usually, the fever is the first symptom noticed by parents. The fever rises steadily and may reach maximum temperatures of 103F to 104F.

The runny nose with a profuse watery discharge, nasal congestion, and sneezing becomes prominent. Typically, there is a pronounced cough, which is hoarse, dry, and hacking. Some children may complain of tightening in the chest. The red eyes are characterized by increased tearing, eye pain that may be severe, and sensitivity to light. Other symptoms that are frequently observed during the prodromal phase include fatigue, irritability, a decreased appetite, a headache, abdominal pain, and a dry mouth and throat. Koplik spots are the peculiar spots present on the buccal mucosa and are considered to be a diagnostic/pathognomic feature of measles/rubeola in the prodromal stage.

2) The eruptive phase

Approximately two to four days after the onset of the symptoms, the rash appears, marking the beginning of the rash phase. The symptoms of the prodromal phase worsen with the onset of the rash, but then begin to decrease in severity. The measles rash is a flat or slightly raised rash and is not itchy. It first appears as irregular spots on the upper forehead or behind the ears and on the neck. Within 24 hours, it progresses to the entire face, head, and neck. Over the next two to four days, the rash extends to the chest, back, and extremities (as seen in the image shown), including the palms of the hands and the soles of the feet. It remains most prominent on the face, especially on the cheeks.

3) The recovery phase

After four to five days, the rash begins to subside, marking the beginning of the recovery phase. Sometimes, a fine flaking of the skin is noted as the rash fades. About 10 to 14 days after developing the rash, the child is back to a normal level of activity.

The period of communicability is approximately 4 days before and 4 days after the appearance of the rash. Isolation of the patient for a week from the onset of rash more than covers the period of communicability.

choices.text: It takes 14 days for the inner square to become darker than outer circle
It takes 14 days for the inner square and outer circle to reach the same color

questions.solution:
The correct statement is option 2.

The given scenario mentions VVM 14 (vaccine vial monitor 14), where 14 indicates the VVM number. It is the time in days for the inner square to reach the color of the outer circle when the vial is exposed to a constant temperature of 37°C. This color change signifies the discard point of the vial.

Vaccine Vial Monitors (VVM) are heat-sensitive indicators that are routinely used to monitor vaccine viability as the vaccine vial moves across the supply chain. It records cumulative heat exposure through a gradual change in color.

There are currently 4 types of VVMs, they are chosen to match the heat sensitivity of the vaccines based on the VVM number. 

  • VVM 30: High Stability
  • VVM 14: Medium Stability
  • VVM 7: Moderate Stability
  • VVM 2: Least Stable

If the color of the inner square is the same or is darker than the outer circle, it indicates that the vaccine has been exposed to high temperatures and should be discarded.

Purpose of VVMs:

  • Ensures that vaccines damaged by heat are not administered
  • Decision on which vaccines to be kept after a cold chain break occurs, minimizing unnecessary vaccine wastage
  • Decision on which vaccine is to be used first. Vaccines showing significant heat exposure should be used before those that show lower heat exposure, even if their expiry date is longer

There are two different locations for VVMs :

  • On the label of the vaccine: The vaccine vial, once opened, can be kept for subsequent immunization sessions for up to 28 days, regardless of the formulation of the product
  • In a location other than on the label (e.g., cap or neck of ampoule): The vaccine vial, once opened should be discarded at the end of the immunization session or within six hours of opening, whichever comes first, regardless of the formulation of the product

questions.text: A patient presents with sudden-onset fever, chills, headache, and painful inguinal lymphadenopathy. There is a history of rodent infestation at his farm. He is diagnosed with a disease transmitted by the vector shown in the image below. Identify the type of zoonosis and the type of biological transmission in this disease.
questions.solution:
The given image above is of a rat flea, which transmits plague bacilli. The type of zoonosis is meta-zoonosis, and the type of biological transmission is propagative transmission. In propagative biological transmission, the disease agent only multiplies in the vector but there is no change in form. Metazoonosis refers to zoonoses that require both vertebrates and invertebrates to complete their infectious cycle.

Zoonoses: These are diseases and infections that are naturally transmitted between other vertebrate animals and man.

Classification of zoonoses on the basis of their reservoir hosts:

  • Anthropozoonoses
  • Zoo-anthroponoses
  • Amphixenoses

Classification of zoonoses on the basis of the life cycle of the infecting agent:

Require more than one vertebrate host is needed to complete the developmental cycle and no invertebrate host

Transmitted by invertebrate vectors, in which the infective agent develops/multiplies and after a period of extrinsic period of incubation is transmitted to another vertebrate host.

Biological transmission in vector-borne diseases:

  • Propagative - The disease agent only multiplies in the vector and there is no change in form. e.g., Plague bacilli in rat fleas.
  • Cyclo-propagative - The agent changes in form and in number. e.g., Malarial parasites in mosquitoes.
  • Cyclo-developmental - The agent undergoes only developmental changes and not multiplication. e.g., Microfilaria in mosquitoes.
  • Transovarial - The infectious agent is transmitted vertically in the vector, from parent to progeny. e.g., Rickettsia rickettsii in ticks.
  • Transstadial - The infectious agent stays with the vector from one stage of its life cycle to the next. e.g., Borrelia burgdorferi in ticks.

Plague is a zoonotic disease. The plague bacillus is a natural parasite in rodents and the infection is transmitted amongst them by rat fleas. In the flea, the bacilli multiply and block the proventriculus. When such a blocked flea bites another rodent, the blood, mixed with the bacteria is regurgitated into the bite, transmitting the infection.

When a diseased rat dies (rat fall), the fleas may bite human beings, causing the plague, which usually manifests as sudden onset of fever and painful lymphadenopathy. Several species of fleas act as vectors. 

Human plague occurs in 3 clinical forms:

Bubonic plague is the most common variety. It is characterized by swollen lymph nodes, which typically develop within a week after an infected flea bite.

Pneumonic plague occurs when bubonic plague spreads to the lungs. It is the most virulent form of plague, and an infected person may transmit the disease via droplets to other humans.

Septicemic plague occurs when the bacteria enter the bloodstream directly and multiply there.

2. Cyclo-propagative

  • The agent changes in form and in number.
  • E.g., Malarial parasites in mosquitoes.

3. Cyclo-developmental

  • The agent undergoes only developmental changes and not multiplication.
  • E.g., Microfilaria in mosquitoes.

4. Transovarial

  • Infectious agent is transmitted vertically in the vector, from parent to progeny.
  • E.g., Rickettsia rickettsii in ticks.

5. Transstadial

  • The infectious agent stays with the vector from one stage of its life cycle to the next.
  • E.g., Borrelia burgdorferi in ticks.

Related Pearl: Rat Fleas

  • Rat fleas (Xenopsylla cheopis) belong to the genus Xenopsylla.
  • Their morphology includes a conical head, absent neck, a thorax with 3 segments, and an abdomen with 10 segments. They have three pairs of legs and no wings.
  • The four stages in their life cycle are egg, larva, pupa, and adult.
  • They cannot fly but can leap up to 6 inches horizontally.
  • They transmit diseases by biting, mechanical transmission, and feces.
  • Flea indices that are used in flea surveys are the general flea index, specific flea index, percentage incidence of flea species, and rodent infestation rate.
  • Rat fleas are vectors for endemic typhus (murine typhus), chiggerosis, bubonic plague, and Hymenolepis diminuta.
  • Insecticidal control is mainly by 10% DDT.
  • Resistance to DDT, gamma-HCH, and dieldrin has been recorded.
  • Repellants like diethyltoluamide and benzyl benzoate are efficient.
  • Rodent control also aims to reduce flea infestation.

questions.solution:

A symposium is a series of speeches on a selected subject by experts. Each expert presents an aspect of the subject briefly, after which the audience is allowed to ask questions.There is no discussion among symposium members. The chairman makes a comprehensive summary at the end of the session.

Health interventions that involve long-term compliance such as cessation of smoking, obesity reduction; group discussions are considered valuable. There should be a leader to start the subject and to ensure equal participation, preventing side conversations and summarize the subject in the end. A recorder of the discussion is desirable.

questions.text: A screening test was carried out among 124 population and 20 had the disease. Twenty-two showed positive tests among which 15 had the disease. What is the sensitivity of the test?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, the sensitivity of the test is 75%.

Out of the 22 positive results, only 15 had the disease and these are true positives. The remaining 7 people are false positives as they got the positive result but have no disease.

Out of the 20 people who had the disease, only 15 tested positive. The remaining 5 people are false negatives as they got a negative result despite having the disease.

The sensitivity of a test is calculated as:

True Positive / (True positives + False Negatives ) × 100

= 15 / (15+5) × 100

= 15 / 20 × 100

= 0.75 × 100

Sensitivity = 75%

Related Pearl: Validity of a Screening Test

  • Validity/ accuracy of a screening test depends upon the sensitivity, specificity, and predictive accuracy of the test.
  • It represents the closeness to a true value/ actual value.
  • These are the inherent properties of a screening test.
  • PPV and NPV are dependent on the Prevalence of disease.
  • Sensitivity & Specificity are independent of prevalence of disease.

questions.text: You are an intern at a hospital that has adopted Baby-friendly Hospital Initiative (BFHI). This global initiative aims to:
questions.solution:
The Baby-friendly Hospital Initiative (BFHI) is a global initiative that aims to promote breastfeeding. It is sponsored by the World Health Organization and the United Nations Children's Fund.

It recommends 10 steps to successful breastfeeding.

They are split into critical management procedures and key clinical practice. Integration of all these steps ensures good breastfeeding practices. The implementation guidance for BFHI emphasizes the strategies to promote universal coverage and ensure sustainability over time. The guidance focuses on the integration of the programme in the healthcare system and ensures the implementation of these steps in all levels of health facilities in the nation. 

Related Pearl: Baby-friendly hospital initiative (revised 2018)

Ten steps to successful breastfeeding (Revised 2018)

Critical management procedures

1  a. Comply fully with the International Code of Marketing of Breast-milk Substitutes and relevant World Health Assembly resolutions.

    b. Have a written infant feeding policy that is routinely communicated to staff and parents.

    c. Establish ongoing monitoring and data-management systems.

2. Ensure that staff has sufficient knowledge, competence, and skills to support breastfeeding.

Key clinical practices

3. Discuss the importance and management of breastfeeding with pregnant women and their families.

4. Facilitate immediate and uninterrupted skin-to-skin contact and support mothers to initiate breastfeeding as soon as possible after birth.

5. Support mothers to initiate and maintain breastfeeding and manage common difficulties.

6. Do not provide breastfed newborns any food or fluids other than breast milk, unless medically indicated.

7. Enable mothers and their infants to remain together and to practice rooming-in 24 hours a day.

8. Support mothers to recognize and respond to their infants’ cues for feeding.

9. Counsel mothers on the use and risks of feeding bottles, teats, and pacifiers.

10. Coordinate discharge so that parents and their infants have timely access to ongoing support and care.

questions.text: While conducting a screening camp for coronary heart disease, you encounter the following people. Who among them is at the highest risk for developing this disease?

choices.text: A person who is competitive and ambitious
A person who is calm and relaxed
A person who tends to suppress their emotions
An introverted person with negative affectivity

questions.solution:
A person who is competitive and ambitious is said to have a type A personality. Such people are more prone to develop coronary heart disease (CHD). Personality type is a non-modifiable risk factor for CHD.

Risk factors for coronary heart disease are:

  • Modifiable:
    • Cigarette smoking
    • High blood pressure
    • Elevated serum cholesterol
    • Diabetes
    • Obesity
    • Sedentary habits
    • Stress
  • Non-modifiable:
    • Age
    • Sex
    • Family history
    • Genetic factors
    • Personality 

Option B: A calm and relaxed person is said to have a type B personality.

Option C: A person who tends to suppress their emotions, especially negative emotions, is said to have a type C personality.

Option D: A person with negative affectivity and social inhibition is said to have a type D personality.

questions.text:
All of the following are true about pyrethrum except:

(DDT: Dichloro-diphenyl-trichloroethane)

choices.text: Residual action is as good as DDT
Can be used synergistically with DDT

questions.solution:
The residual action of pyrethrum is not as good as that of DDT. The drawback of using pyrethrum is that, it lacks the residual action of DDT and other insecticides.

Pyrethrum is an insecticide that has a vegetable origin. It is extracted from the flowers of Chrysanthemum cinerariafolium. The flowers contain 4 active principles that are pyrethrins I & II and cinerins I & II. All these active principles are nerve poisons. These effectively reduce the number of mosquitoes but the effect is temporary as it has no residual action. 

Pyrethrum is used as space sprays and is sprayed into the atmosphere in the form of fog/mist to kill insects immediately on contact. The standard reference aerosol space spray recommended by WHO contains pyrethrum and DDT as they have a synergistic action.

The image given below is of the flowers of Chrysanthemum cinerariafolium.

Related Pearl: Insecticides

Contact poisons

  • Natural: Pyrethrum, rotenone, derris, nicotine, mineral oils
  • Synthetic:
    • Organo-chlorine compounds: DDT, methoxychlor, HCH, lindane, chlordane, heptachlor, dieldrin, aldrin, toxaphene, kepone, mirex.
    • Repellants: Benzyl benzoate, indalone, meta-diethyltoluamide, dimethyl phthalate, ethyl hexanediol.
    • Organo-phosphorus compounds: Chlorthion (aryl), diazinon (aryl), demethoate, malathion (alkyl), fenthion, parathion (aryl), trichlorfon (alkyl), runnel, abale, naled, chlorpyrifos, fenitrothion, dicapthon.
    • Carbamates: Carbaryl, dimetilan, propoxur, pyrolan.
    • Synthetic pyrethroids: Prothrin, resmethrin, bioresmethrin, permethrin, proparthin, tetramethrin
  • Stomach poisons: Paris green, sodium fluoride.
  • Fumigants: Hydrogen cyanide, methyl bromide, sulphur dioxide, carbon disulphide.

Attacks nerves of insects but doesn’t cause immediate death. White amorphous powder. Contains 70 – 80% of para-para isomers, which is the most active fraction of DDT. Has residual action up to 18 months. Used as a residual spray.Least toxic organo-chlorine compound.
HCH (hexachlorocyclo-hexane) Synthesized by Michael Faraday. Normal HCH contains 13 – 16% of gamma isomer. Gamma-HCH or lindane has 99% gamma isomer.Short residual action – 3 months.
Malathion Least toxicity of all organophosphorus compounds. Used as an ultra-low volume spray.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most logical sequence?
questions.solution:
Disease → Impairment → Disability → Handicap is the most logical sequence among the given options.

Disease is a state of physiological/psychological dysfunction.

Impairment is any loss or abnormality in normal structure or function.

Disability is the inability to carry out normal actions due to impairment.

Handicap is the disadvantage due to disability that limits fulfilment of a role that is normal.

questions.text: A patient who was admitted to the ICU due to a road traffic accident later developed pneumonia. What time duration is required to declare it to be a hospital-acquired infection?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, any infection occurring more than 48 hours after admission is usually considered a hospital-acquired infection. 

A hospital-acquired infection is defined as an infection acquired during hospital care that is not present or incubating at admission. It is acquired due to cross-infection of a patient by other patients, hospital staff. It is a determinant of the poor quality of service provided by the hospital. It is also called nosocomial infections.

The criteria for surveillance of nosocomial respiratory infections are:

  1. Cough
  2. Purulent sputum
  3. New infiltrate on radiograph consistent with infection

If any 2 of the above given 3 clinical features are present, a diagnosis of hospital-acquired respiratory infection is made.

questions.text: A pregnant woman has come for her first antenatal visit at 10 weeks of gestation. How many more antenatal visits does she require to fulfill the minimum requirements as per the Maternal and Child Health program?
questions.solution:
This patient requires 3 more antenatal visits in order to fulfill the minimum requirements according to the Maternal and Child Health Program (MCH).

The minimum number of antenatal visits according to MCH is 4.

  • 1st visit – within 12 weeks, preferably as soon as the pregnancy is suspected.
  • 2nd visit – between 14 and 26 weeks
  • 3rd visit – between 28 and 34 weeks
  • 4th visit – between 36 weeks and term

The minimum number of antenatal visits according to the WHO is 8. Ideally, pregnant women should attend antenatal visits according to the following schedule:

  • Once a month during the first 7 months
  • Twice a month during the 8th month
  • Once a week, thereafter if everything is normal.

questions.text: Which among the following is COVID appropriate behaviour?

choices.text: Maintain a distance of at least 2 feet in all public places
Remove the upper string of the mask first followed by the lower string
Tie the lower string of the mask first followed by upper string
The external pleats of the mask should face downwards

questions.solution:
The external pleats of the mask should face downwards is the only COVID appropriate behaviour in the above options.

 COVID appropriate behaviours prevent the transmission of COVID 19 infection. Important ones are:

  • Greet without physical contact
  • Maintain a distance of at least 6 feet in all public places.
  • Wear reusable hand-made face-cover or mask, at all times. While wearing a mask the nasal clip should be present over the nose and external pleats should face downwards. Open the mask pleats so that the mask covers the mouth and nose. Tie the upper strings of the mask first followed by lower strings. Do not touch the front of the mask. Replace the mask every 8 hours or when damp. While removing, the mask, remove the lower string of the mask first followed by the upper string. Dispose the mask and wash your hands.
  • Avoid touching eyes, nose, and mouth
  • Maintain respiratory hygiene. Cover your nose and mouth when you cough or sneeze with a tissue or handkerchief. If there is no tissue or handkerchief, always cover your nose and mouth with a bent elbow before coughing or sneezing. Immediately wash your hands after that.
  • Wash hands frequently and thoroughly or sanitise with alcohol-based sanitiser.
  • Regularly clean and disinfect frequently touched surfaces by wearing gloves.
  • Do not spit in the open
  • Avoid unnecessary travel and discourage crowd and social gatherings.

questions.text: Which among the following is not a risk factor for severe illness in a patient with COVID-19?
questions.solution:
Young age is not a risk factor for severe illness in a patient with COVID-19.

Although severe illness can occur in otherwise healthy individuals of any age, it predominantly occurs in adults with advanced age or underlying medical comorbidities. The comorbidities associated with severe illness and mortality include:

  • Cardiovascular disease
  • Diabetes mellitus
  • Hypertension
  • Chronic lung disease
  • Cancer
  • Chronic kidney disease
  • Obesity (body mass index ≥30)
  • Smoking

Immunosuppression is also presumed to be a risk factor for severe illness and mortality, but this has not yet been definitively demonstrated in studies.

questions.text:
You are a medical officer working in a rural PHC. A primipara, who is 26 weeks pregnant comes to the PHC for covid vaccination. You explain to her all about the vaccination and the minor side effects she may experience post-vaccination. Which of the following is a side effect of COVID-19 vaccination in pregnant women that needs immediate attention?

PHC- Primary healthcare center

choices.text: Small pinpoint hemorrhage beyond the vaccination site

questions.solution:
Small pinpoint haemorrhage beyond the vaccination site is a side effect of COVID-19 vaccination that needs immediate attention.

Like any medicine, a vaccine may have side effects which are normally mild. After getting the vaccine, the pregnant women can get mild fever, pain at injection site, or feel unwell (malaise) for 1-3 days.

Very rarely, the beneficiary may experience some of the following symptoms after getting the injection, which may need immediate attention.

  • Shortness of breath (difficulty in breathing)
  • Chest pain
  • Pain in limbs/pain on pressing the limbs or swelling in the limbs (arm or calf)
  • Small pinpoint haemorrhages (petechial) or bruising of the skin beyond the vaccination site
  • Persistent abdominal pain with or without vomiting
  • Seizures in the absence of previous history of seizures with or without vomiting
  • Severe and persistent headaches with or without vomiting (in the absence of previous history of migraine or chronic headache)
  • Weakness/paralysis of limbs or any particular side of the body
  • Persistent vomiting without any obvious reason
  • Blurred vision / pain in the eyes

Any other symptom or condition that is of concern to the recipient or the family.

 COVID-19 vaccination during pregnancy:

  • MoHFW has recently approved the vaccination of pregnant women against COVID-19.
  • COVID-19 vaccine can be taken anytime during pregnancy and should be taken at the earliest.
  • If any woman has been infected with COVID-19 during pregnancy, then she should be vaccinated soon after delivery.
  • COVID-19 vaccine is safe in pregnancy.
